bibl.title: Letter from Hermann Hagedorn to Jefferson Randolph Kean, December 20, 1929

div1.p: Hagedorn relates a conversation with General McCoy concerning Wood's announcement of the Yellow Fever Commission's findings, in 1900. He also comments on Gorgas' sanitary work in Havana.

div1.head: Letter from Hermann Hagedorn to Jefferson Randolph Kean, December 20, 1929

opener.dateline:
HERMANN HAGEDORN
STUDY 27, LIBRARY OF CONGRESS, WASHINGTON, D. C.
RESIDENCE: 4767 INDIAN LANE N.W.
TELEPHONE CLEVELAND 4588
December 20,
1929.

div1.p:
Thank you so much for the information
given me in your letter of December 14th. In con-
nection with that birthday dinner, you will be interest-
ed in an answer to a query which I addressed to General
McCoy after my talk with you. He writes:

"I am absolutely sure, and ready to hang
myself on it, that General Wood told us, the members
of his staff, about the definite solution of the Yellow
Fever problem at his fortieth birthday dinner on
October 9, 1900.

“Besides myself, there were at that dinner
General Scott, General Greble, Colonel Edward Carpenter,
M. E. Hanna, now Minister to Nicaragua, General William
Murray Black, now living in Washington, and probably
some others; but those are the ones that I remember.”

In answer to your question whether General Wood
spurred General Gorgas on in his campaign against the
mosquitoes in February, 1901, General McCoy writes as
follows:

"In reply to your last inquiry about Gorgas
and Kean, I would be inclined to think that Kean's remem-
brance is correct, although mine is based simply on
impressions. I do know that, prior to the time in-
dicated, Gorgas did not cut much of a figure as Sanitary
Officer of Havana, but during the last period, dating
from about February, 1901, Gorgas worked most effectively
and loyally, and General Wood was back of him all the
time in both urge and encouragement.

“I think Gorgas should be given great credit
for his entire work as Sanitary Officer in Havana, but
I remember with pride that General Wood was largely
responsible for helping him to find himself, both in
Cuba and in Panama.”
div1.closer:
Yours sincerely, Hermann Hagedorn Colonel J. R. Kean
Army Medical Museum
Washington D C.
